algorithms/deutsch.html.title: Deutsch
algorithms/deutsch.html.description:
The Deutsch Algorithm was developed by David Deutsch (1992). This was the first algorithm that showed the potential computational power of quantum computation. The Algorithm demonstrates typical features and ingredients of quantum computation for example Quantum Superposition and Quantum Entanglement. Consider a single bit A black box that computes a function We do not know (and do not care) how, but every evaluation of f is extremely costly (e. g. in terms of computational time) Thus, we want to limit the number of evaluations of f to an absolute minimum 4 possibilities So there are two cases: : f is constant, all bits are the same. or : f is balanced, half of the bits are 0, the other half 1.We are not interested in the individual values of and but only in the global property whether f is constant or balanced. First compute individual values and . We get more information than we need, namely on the individual values. In a second step we compare the two values We need two evaluations Claim: We can do better, with a single evaluation of f. We won‘t (in fact must not) obtain any information on the individual values of f, yet we will be able to answer the question We will use two qubits, in an initial product state We will use a two-qubit unitary transformation Here denotes addition modulo 2 The transformation leaves the first qubit unchanged and acts on the second one as follows: If y is not changed If y is flipped Remarks: After the transformation, the state can not be written as a product state: is unitary and Hermitian because Every application of requires one evaluation of f For we get: This state contains both functions in superposition in the second qubit and in general entangled with the first qubit If we measure the first qubit the second qubit collapses to either or with probability 1/2. This is not better than one evaluation in a classical algorithm because we get to know the both individual values (with uncertainty). It is even worse.
Quantum Parallelism is an ingredient for speedup but not enough. We also need Algorithmic Interference, i. e. a way of constructively interfering the paths such that the information we are interested in (f balanced or constant) is amplified, and the information we don‘t care about (individual values and ) becomes inaccessible. If we prepare the -state we get the following: For we get: So the first qubit is measured as for a constant function and for a balanced function The information of the individual function values appear as a global phase factor () which can not be measured directly. Final Step: measurement the probability of the -state is 1 for f constant the probability of the -state is 1 for f balanced
With specific preparation of and an Oracle which is an implementation of Remarks: We evaluated f only once
Speedup due to Quantum Parallelism is 2 (Constant)

algorithms/deutsch-josza.html.title: Deutsch-Josza
algorithms/deutsch-josza.html.description:
The Deutsch-Josza Algorithm is the multifunction generalization of the Deutsch Algorithm. For N=, we are given an N-bit String as input such that either: all have the same value (“constant“) N/2 of the are 0, and are 1 (“balanced“) Here the index from to , to label all elements. We can view this again as a function Goal: find out whether x is constant or balanced Note: We are not interested in the individual values , but only in the global property whether x is constant or balanced N=8, n=3 constant balanced First compute individual values In this step we obtain more information than we need, namely on the individual values In a second step, we compare the values- A classical algorithm requires in general evaluations of x to answer the question (Worst case, if is the same as all before we know for certainty that the function is constant. With less evaluations we can only guess) Claim: we can do better, with a single evaluation of f. We won‘t (in fact must not) obtain any information on the individual values , if we will be able to answer the question
Many quantum algorithms work with queries (including Grover and Shor) We can think of the inputs as an N-bit memory, which we can access at any point of our choice (RAM) A memory access is via a so-called „black-box“, which outputs bit on input As a quantum operation, this is realized by the (n+1)-qubit unitary , with address register of n qubits target bit Remarks: After the transformation, the state is not necessarily a product state () , unless is one compuational basis state is unitary and hermitian because Every application of requires one evaluation of
We want to prepare an equal-weight superposition off all basis states on the first n qubits with H-Gates If then we get The state contains all function values in superposition in the target qubit, and (in general) entangled with the first n qubits
But we can access the information: If we measure the first qubits, the superposition collapses with probability to any computational state . This is not better than one evaluation in a classical algorithm. Similar to Deutsch we need Algorithmic Interference here. If then we get
(see Deutsch)
So the action of the phase Oracle is which does nothing if and adds a phase if , the oracle can be thus noted as
Now we reapply H-Gates and get the following in total: For is constant, our state is if all and if all because this is the only that survives. So if we measure this state we know for certainty that we have a constant function. If we measure a different state we know for certainty that we have a balanced function. We have again a global phase which is inaccessible which is important! The Deutsch-Josza algorithm can be solved with certainty using only one quantum query and other operations In contrast any classical deterministic algorithm needs at least N/2 +1 queries Classical algorithm can solve this problem efficiently if we allow for a small error probability and can be in general better if we allow this It is identical to the Deutsch-Josza algorithm but with the additional property , the final measurement yields a with certainty
Per definition of the H-Gates the following holds: After step (3) we have (with inserting ) Start with an register Apply a Hadamard to end the qubit Apply a phase oracle query Apply another Hadamard to each qubit Measure the final state

algorithms/grover.html.title: Grover
algorithms/grover.html.description:
The quantum search algorithm was proposed by Lev Grover in 1994.
Search through a search space of N elements.
Assume for convenience n bits of information to label one element
Assume that the problem of interest has exactly solutions (typically ) How fast can we find at least one of the solutions?
A particular instance of a problem is conveniently represented by a function , which takes as an input an integer , , and yields if is a solution to the search problem if is not a solution to the search problem
Hamiltonian path problem:
A particular graph specifies .
Inputs correspond to paths (i.e. sequences of vertices)
$$
f(x) = \begin{cases}
1 & \text{if } x \text{ is a Hamiltonian path in } G \
0 & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}\begin{align}
| \Psi \rangle &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \sum_x | x\rangle = \frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \left(\sum^{’’} |x \rangle + \sum^{’} |x \rangle \right) \
&= \frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \left(\sqrt{N-M} \frac{1}{\sqrt{N-M}} \sum^{’’} |x \rangle + \sqrt{M} \frac{1}{\sqrt{M}} \sum^{’} |x \rangle \right) \
&= \sqrt{\frac{N-M}{N}} | \alpha \rangle + \sqrt{\frac{M}{N}} | \beta \rangle \
&= \sqrt{1-\varepsilon} | \alpha \rangle + \sqrt{\varepsilon} | \beta \rangle
\end{align}\begin{align}
O | \psi \rangle &= O(\sqrt{1-\varepsilon} | \alpha \rangle + \sqrt{\varepsilon} | \beta \rangle) \
&= \sqrt{1-\varepsilon} | \alpha \rangle - \sqrt{\varepsilon} | \beta \rangle \
&= (\sqrt{1-\varepsilon} | \alpha \rangle + \sqrt{\varepsilon} | \beta \rangle)- 2\sqrt{\varepsilon} | \beta \rangle \
&= |\psi \rangle - 2 \sqrt{\varepsilon} | \beta \rangle \
UO |\psi \rangle &= (2 |\psi \rangle \langle \psi | - \mathbb{I})(|\psi \rangle - 2 \sqrt{\varepsilon} | \beta \rangle) \
&= 2 |\psi \rangle - |\psi \rangle - 4 \sqrt{\varepsilon} \langle \psi|\beta\rangle |\psi \rangle + 2\sqrt{\varepsilon} |\beta \rangle \
&= (1-4 \varepsilon)|\psi \rangle+2\sqrt{\varepsilon} | \beta \rangle \
&= (1-4\varepsilon) (\sqrt{1-\varepsilon} | \alpha \rangle + \sqrt{\varepsilon} | \beta \rangle)+2\sqrt{\varepsilon} | \beta \rangle \
&= (1-4 \varepsilon) \sqrt{1-\varepsilon} |\alpha \rangle + \sqrt{\varepsilon}(3-4 \varepsilon)|\beta \rangle
\end{align}\begin{align}
p_\mathrm{fail} &= \cos\left({\frac{2k+1}{2}\theta}\right)^2 \
&= \cos\left({\frac{2\tilde{k}+1}{2}\theta} + (k-\tilde{k}) \theta \right)^2 \
&= \cos\left(\frac{\pi}{2} + (k-\tilde{k}) \theta \right)^2 \
&= \sin\left((k-\tilde{k}) \theta \right)^2 \
&\leq \sin\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)^2
\mathrm{for} , |k-\tilde{k}| \leq \frac{1}{2}, \mathrm{and} , \theta \ll 1 \
&= \frac{M}{N} ; \mathrm{small}
\end{align}

algorithms/oracle.html.title: Oracle
algorithms/oracle.html.description: The oracle does nothing with the state if it is the solution. If it is the solution it adds a Phase (for example -1). An oracle is a black box whose internal working are not important, the oracle has the ability to recognize the problem

algorithms/quantum-phase-estimation.html.title: Quantum Phase Estimation
algorithms/quantum-phase-estimation.html.description:
This makes use of QFT.Suppose that a unitary has an eigenvector with eigenvalue , where is unknown. The goal is to estimate (Note that ). Assumptions: We have black boxes that prepare and peform controlled- operations, for suitable non-negative integers We will have two qubit registers: The first register contains qubits intitially in The choice of will depend on The desired number of digits of accuracy of the estimate of The desired success probability with which we wish the phase estimation procedure to be successful The second register begins in , containing as many qubits as are necessary to store
First we create an unbiased superposition by putting H-Gates for all qubits for the first register. Then we do controlled- operations on the second register which is controlled by the th qubit on the first register. Consider one qubit of the first register, and All computational basis states are encoded in binary representation . Example: so the output state for t=4 k=3 is . The measurement of the qubits on the first register provides us exactly. Hadamard gates on all qubits of register 1 Controlled- operations on the second register, with raised to successive power of 2, controlled by the qubits of the first register Apply the inverse QFT Measure the qubits of the first register in the computational basis In general can‘t be written exactly as binary -bit expansion One can show that if one wants to get an approximate estimate for to an accuracy , and one wants the probability to obtain an estimate of this precision to be at least , one needs to choose the number of qubits in the first register as $$ t= n + \left[\log{\left(1+\frac{1}{2 \varepsilon}\right)}\right]
It is also possible to estimate the phase in an iterative process. First the following circuit with controlled by the ancillas is being applied with a measurement in the X-basis, for qubits 2,…,n additional unitaries controlled by the th classical bit given by the X-measurement are added before the measurement.

algorithms/shorγçÿs-algorithm.html.title: ShorΓÇÿs algorithm
algorithms/shorγçÿs-algorithm.html.description: The problem of factoring: Given a positive composite integer number , what are the prime factors multiplied together equaling ? A fast algorithm for order finding can be converted into a fast algorithm for factoring Factoring is believed to be hard on classical computers: For an -bit integer , the best classical algorithms known to date (number field sieve) require roughly operations. This is exponential in the number of bits describing the number We can find a factor of if we find a non-trivial solution of . There are always two trivial solutions: and However if N is divisible by two distinct odd primes, these are at least two more non-trivial square roots in (i.e. among the set of numbers between 1 and , which are coprime with N):If , then neither nor is a multiple of . In that case, the greatest common divisors and must each be proper divisors of , i.e. prime factors we are looking for. How can we find a non-trivial square root ? Choose a random integer , , check whether is coprime of . If it‘s not coprime, and share a prime factor, which we can easily find and we are done. If is coprime of , then run the Quantum Order Finding algorithm to find :In other words if we are lucky and the order is even, then is a square root of 1. We know for sure that , since is the smallest integer for which this is true. If we are again lucky and too, then is a non-trivial root. We then can calculate and to find non-trivial prime factors. Calculating gcd is efficient (Euclid‘s algorithm). Choose e.g. order Check: 8 is a non-trivial square root of 1 in . and The number of elements of good coprimes where their order is even and can be determined in the following:If us divisible by distinct odd primes, then at least a fraction of the elements in are good. Thus, for , the probability to pick a good coprime is at least . We need only trials.Shor‘s quantum algorithm for factoring requires runs of the quantum algorithm for order finding. Overall runtime Compared to classical runtime Exponential speedup

gates/single-qubit-gates/single-qubit-ga.description: For classical bits there is only one non-trivial gate, the NOT gate. For qubits there are infinite possible gates. For example the Pauli Gates, the Hadamard-Gate, Phase-Gate and T-Gate.

gates/two-qubit-gates/cnot-gate.html.title: CNOT gate
gates/two-qubit-gates/cnot-gate.html.description: The CNOT gate (or Controlled-NOT gate) is two-qubit operation, where the first qubit is usually referred to as the control qubit and the second qubit as the target qubit. Expressed in basis states, the CNOT gate: leaves the control qubit unchanged and performs a Pauli-X gate on the target qubit when the control qubit is in state ; leaves the target qubit unchanged when the control qubit is in state . is equivalent to adding the value of the control qubit qubit to the value of the second qubit, and writing the result into the second qubit qc.cx(qr[0], qr[1]) # execute CNOT gate with control qubit 0 and target qubit 1

gates/two-qubit-gates/controlled-u-gate..title: Controlled-U Gate
gates/two-qubit-gates/controlled-u-gate..description: U is applied to the second qubit if and only if the first qubit is in state . The CNOT gate is a Controlled-X Gate.

gates/two-qubit-gates/swap-gate.html.title: SWAP Gate
gates/two-qubit-gates/swap-gate.html.description: The swap gate swaps two qubits and can be constructed by a concatenation of CNOTs.

gates/two-qubit-gates/toffoli-gate.html.title: Toffoli Gate
gates/two-qubit-gates/toffoli-gate.html.description: The three-bit Toffoli Gate is a universal reversible logical gate: any reversible circuit can be built from Toffoli gates only. The NOT gate can be realized by and the AND gate by Its action is: Only if the first two input bits are set to 1, the gate inverts the third bit, otherwise the three bits remain all unchanged.Non trivial action:

gates/two-qubit-gates/two-qubit-gates.ht.description: A two qubit gate is a Unitary U acting on 2 qubits.

gates/classical-logic-gates.html.title: Classical Logic Gates
gates/classical-logic-gates.html.description:
Idealized or physical electronic devices that realize a Boolean function: a logical operation performed on one or more binary inputs ( FALSE/TRUE) that produce a single binary output There exists a minimal set of gates to implement any classical Boolean circuit. The set of gates are not unique, one example is {AND, NOT}. An example of a single gate that is universal is the NAND gate.The classical two-bit gates are essentially irreversible and non-invertible: for example from the output of the XOR gate, it is impossible to determine what the inputs a and b were. There is an irretrievable loss of information associated with the irreversible action of the XOR-gate, and other classical two-bit logic gates
The Toffoli Gate is reversible.

gates/clifford-gates.html.title: Clifford Gates
gates/clifford-gates.html.description:
All Pauli Gates are Clifford Gates and the Generator of the Clifford Group: For n qubits one can construct the Pauli group: The n-qubit Clifford group is defined as the n qubit unitaries that normalize the Pauli Group: Note that this only applies for the entire set , not element-wise. Elements of the Clifford group are called Clifford gates. : Hadamard : The 16 Elements of are mapped onto But : , : : - etc.
The Clifford Gates can be generated by only. The Gottesmann-Knill theorem is an important result for efficiency of classical simulation of Clifford Gates. The Clifford Group only reaches a discrete Set of the Bloch Sphere. With the Universal Gate Set every point at the Bloch sphere can be reached.Discussion: Hadamard and CNOT allow to create entangled states. This kind of entanglement alone does not provide an intrinsic quantum speedup! Clifford Gates are not an universal gate set Universal quantum computing requires at least one non-Clifford gate, e.g. the T-gate Important quantum protocols involving only Clifford operations:
Quantum teleportation
Magic state distillation
Quantum Error Correction with stabilizer codes

gates/gates.html.title: Gates
gates/gates.html.description: Gates are unitary operations a.k.a. matrices. Thus the direction of the circuit and equation are opposite.

gates/gottesmann-knill-theorem.html.title: Gottesmann-Knill theorem
gates/gottesmann-knill-theorem.html.description: Quantum circuits of only Clifford Gates can be perfectly simulated efficiently, i. e. in polynomial time, on classical computers.More precisely, circuits involving (i) preparation of qubits in computational basis, (ii) Clifford Gates and (iii) measurements in the computational basis.

gates/measurement.html.title: Measurement
gates/measurement.html.description: Single qubit measurements are a measurement of Z if not specified. Pauli measurements are projections into the eigenstates auf the Pauli Operator. It is also called measurement in the Z-basis or measurements in the computational basis. The qubit wire ends with a measurement, unless a classical trigger is set with a classical bit from the measurement.

gates/solovay-kitaev-theorem.html.title: Solovay-Kitaev-Theorem
gates/solovay-kitaev-theorem.html.description: A single-qubit can be approximated to accuracy using gates from the discrete gate set. This is a poly-logarithmic increase- very slow (in particular not an exponential increase in ).

lecture-information/overview.html.title: Overview
lecture-information/overview.html.description:
BLOCK 1 (tentative list of topics covered)1 - Overview and Introduction2 - Quantum Gates and Circuits3-A - Deutsch Algorithm3-B - Deutsch-Jozsa Algorithm and Bernstein-Vazirani Problem4 - Classical Computation
5 - Universality of Quantum Gates
6 - Computational Complexity
7 - Grover Quantum Search Algorithm
8 - Quantum Fourier Transform
9 - Quantum Phase Estimation
10 - Quantum Order Finding
11-A - Shor Algorithm for Factoring BLOCK 2Lecture 1 : Rules of Quantum Theory We formulate rules of quantum theory characterizing what is possible and what is not, making the role of information explicit.• For open quantum ”systems” some information got lost : Non-pure events / circuits require a mathematically more complicated description which is, however, closer to an operational understanding of what goes on in the physics lab and to classical theory• For closed quantum ”systems” there is no information that can get lost : Pure events allow a mathematically simpler description which is, however, not directly related to the physics in the lab or classical theoryWe explore several ways these two formalisms are related. The goal is to master both and to be able switch between them at will.The quantum rules mathematically contruct probabilities from Hilbert-space vectors/operators subject to a physical contraint of causality. But other than this, the rules of quantum theory are simply mathematically postulated without any deeper physical motivation beyond “experiments conﬁrm their predictions”. This leaves us to “discover the physics” by solving operational tasks of information processing. This is what Lecture 2-5 do systematically.Terminology State vectors, density operators, ensembles, POVMs, channels, operations, instruments, isometries, non-orthogonal setsLecture 2 : Observations on Preparations With the quantum rules in hand we ﬁrst study the simplest quantum circuit where a single system A is prepared and then observations are performed to extract information contained in their joint probabilities : We verify that the closed-system rules indeed only describe pure preparations based on the simulatability of the probability distributions that they can generate, and likewise for observations. We then analyze non-pure preparations of open systems by bringing these into a standard simulation form, identifying what is “quantum” about them, and likewise for observations : • Non-pure preparations are always mixtures with information encoded in the probabilities of mixing (like classically) but also in the freedom of choice of the pure states that are being mixed (unlike classically)• Non-pure observation are always coarse-grainings involving pure observations (like classically) but the freedom of choosing these prohibits the simulation of any measurement by post-processing of a single pure observation device (unlike classically)This “Non-uniqueness of prepation reﬁnement” and “No post-processings of ideal measurement” turn out to be the same thing.
We then analyze 2 basic tasks of information extraction :
• In tomography, we extract complete information characterizing an unknown preparation by a D-outcome observation on the quantum system• In perfectly distinguishing, a known set of preparations is identiﬁed by a d-outcome observation device without extracting complete information about these states(“Which one is it?”)(“Which of these is it)These task are related by D=d 2 expressing an “information gap” : Tomography is quadratically harder than perfectly distinguishing This is the operational signiﬁcance of the quantum rule “States are d×d positive matrices on a Hilbert space”Terminology Measurement in orthogonal basis, IC-POVMs Lecture 3 : Steering a pure preparationWe next consider a quantum circuit where two systems are jointly prepared. A local measurement is performed to extract information from one system B and we investigate what classical communication B→A implies for the description of the other remote system A
With communication, this results in remote steering.
steeringThe solution of this operational task leads to a characterization of all pure, correlated states These correlations are not simulatable by coarse-graining of coordinated local preparations (unlike classically)
Without communication there is no remote eﬀect as dictated by causality.
The solution of the inverse operational task, puriﬁcation, leads to a pure, correlated simulation of any remote non-pure state of an open system (classically impossible). The “non-uniqueness of mixture reﬁnement of preparation” of Lecture 2 is fully characterized.
The non-locality of entanglement is shown to limited by the locality of quantum tomography, the ability to characterize any quantum state by local observations (like classically): Entanglement is monogamous correlation, non-shareable by more than 2 parties
Terminology Entanglement, Schmidt decomposition of bipartite vectors, SVD, partial traceBLOCK 3 (tentative list of topics covered)
12-A - Basic Concepts of Quantum Error Correction
12-B - Stabiliser Formalism and Complete Codes
13-A - Introduction to Topological QEC Codes
13-B - Fault-Tolerant Universal Gates and Scalable ArchitecturesBLOCK 4Lecture 4-5 systematically performs the analogous steps of Lecture 2-3 for transformations (measurements, evolutions) thereby completing the framework of essential results of quantum information theory :Lecture 4 : TransformationsThe next level of complexity is a quantum circuit involving transformations of the preparation of a single system. These can extract information about input state A before a further, ﬁnal observation is made on the disturbed output state B : We verify that the closed-system rules indeed only describe pure transformations by the simulatability of the probability distributions that they generate. The purity of the identity transformation (“trivially doing nothing”) implies that nontrivial result that information-extraction implies disturbance of a quantum system, starting from clear-cut deﬁnitions based on probabilities in the lab. We analyze non-pure transformations of open systems by again bringing them into a standard simulation form and we identify what is “quantum” about them : • A non-pure transformation is always a coarse-grainings of some pure “transition” processes (like in classical theory) but there is freedom of choice in which “transitions” are coarse-grained (unlike classical theory)• A non-pure transformation need not be a mixture (like classical theory)This “non-uniqueness of reﬁnement” of transformations is remiscent of that of for states. This is no coincidence :
We again analyze 2 basic tasks of information extraction :
• Tomography, extracting complete information characterizing an unknown transformation, turns out to be possible by “encoding” the transformation in its modiﬁcation of pure entangled state and “decoding” it by using the corresponding state as resource for teleportation of input to output• Perfectly distinguishing a known set of transformations likewise turns out to be possible by perfectly distinguishing these corresponding states(“Which one is it?”)(“Which of these is it?”)The uncovered preparation-transformation correspondence is a key trick that allows to convert any result about preparations into a result about transformations and vice versa. This is systematically exploited in the ﬁnal lecture.Terminology Kraus operators, (Sudarshan-)Kraus theorem, (de Pillis-)Choi-Jamiolkowski correpondence, HEWJ theorem Lecture 5 : Steering a pure transformationFinally, the most complex quantum circuit we need to consider involves transformations jointly preparing two output systems AB taking input from one system C. A local measurement is applied to extract information from one output B and we investigate what classical communication B→A implies for the transformation outputting to the remote system A :steering
With communication, this results in remote transformation steering.
The solution of this operational task leads to characterization of pure entanglement generating transformations
Without communication there is no remote eﬀect as dictated by causality.
The solution of the inverse operational task, transformation puriﬁcation, leads to a pure simulation of any non-pure transformation with remote output (classically impossible). The “nonuniqueness of transformation reﬁnement” in Lecture 4 is fully characterized.
The non-locality of entanglement generation is likewise shown to limited by the locality of quantum tomography : Entanglement is monogamous correlation, non-shareable by more than 2 parties.
Terminology Schmidt decomposition of isometries, Stinespring dilation, channels, operations, instrumentsWhat will we learn ?By systematically analyzing very basic operational tasks allowed by the rules of quantum theory and switching back and fort between closed- and open-system formalisms, we will derive all essential results in quantum information theory. In doing so, we illustrate :Quantum theory is all about information. Quantum circuits are the calculations.We stress that all the results can be –and often are– derived in mathematical style and discussed in purely mathematical language. This is not wrong, but it does leave the reader interested in physics to ﬁgure out what it is all about.However, we will see time and again that the mathematics naturally follows from the operational physics. This is not a coincidence : All of the mathematics of quantum theory (ﬁnite dimension, without superselection) can be derived by solving the information processing tasks discussed in this lecture, starting from a few operational deﬁnitions and manipulating quantum circuits.BLOCK 11.1 Circuit identities (few simple identities/rules)
1.2 SWAP gates (proof of swap gates and implementation from cnot, does swap gate create entanglement)
1.3 Deutsch algorithm (implementation)
1.4 Deutsch Josza algorithm (implementation)
2.1 Bernstein Vazirani (implementation)
2.3 Controlled-U gates )(controlled U Gate construction from single qubit unitaries)
3.1 n-controlled U gates (Implementation via controlled Vs, logical expression equivalent)
3.2 Grover 2-bit (Implementation)
3.3 Grover 3-bit (Implementation and optimal k)
4.1 Phase estimation (Alternative iterative approach)
4.2 Single qubit measurements on multipartite states (creation of GHZ and W-state with circuits)
4.3 Decomposition of multi qubit unitaries (Implementation of grey code)
5.1 Magic state and T-state injection
5.2 Shor‘s algorithm (Doing algorithm per hand)
5.3 Universal gate sets (alternative gate sets)BLOCK 26.1 Physical validity of mathematical expressions
6.2 Ensemble tomography with orthogonal measurements 7.1 Conclusively distinguishing distinct states
7.3 Tomographic preparation device8.1 Conclusively distinguishing – Implementations10.1 Basic qubit “noise” channels BLOCK 310.2 Quantum Error Correction (QEC) with a 7-Qubit Steane Code (How works and constructing other logical gates (e.g. ))11.1 Quantum error correction of qubit loss (How it works and implementation)Block 412.1 Correspondence Bell states ↔ Pauli transformations
12.2 Teleportation and communication

quantum-computing/computational-complexi.description:
Problems for which finding a solution can be achieved in time that scales polynomials with the size of the problem Examples: Eulerian Path Problem (Königsberg Bridge Problem) Problems for which a solution can be found by a non-deterministic (N) Turing machine in polynomial (P) time.However, solutions can still be checked in polynomial time.Examples: Hamiltonian Cycle Problem Finding a needle in a haystack Knapsack problem (NP-Complete) Sudoku A problem B is NP-complete, if for any problem A in NP there exists a polynomial-time reduction from A to BBounded-error quantum polynomial time is the class of decision problems solvable by a quantum computer in polynomial time, with an error probability of at most 1/3 for all instances.Examples: Grover

quantum-error-correction/3-qubit-code.ht.description:
Distribute an arbitrary quantum state over an entangled state of physical qubits. Encode logical qubit: Basis states or codewords span the codespace, a subspace of the Hilbert space, in which arbitrary logical superpositions live: Encoding: quantum circuit Use two Ancilla qubits initialized in :
Possible occurrence of errors: E.g. bit flip error on qubit 1: How can we find out about the error that occurred on the system? Direct measurement of all qubits would collapse the state into or : Information about and would be lost.
Solution: we realize an indirect measurement, using additional ancilla qubits and syndromes (measurements) and
No information gained about the encoded state ( and coefficients) Strategy corrects up to one -error on any qubit 2 simultaneous errors induce a logical bit flip error Example error: QER fails For 3 simultaneous errors : is not detectable and directly induces a logical bit flip error. Phase flip errors, e.g. also is undetectable and directly induces a logical phase flip error. 3-qubit code is not a complete code.The probability to correct error(s) is the following:
Here for , , thus better protection offered by 3-qubit code.The 3-qubit code can be formulated as a stabilizer QEC code:
The logical operators are and

quantum-error-correction/9-qubit-shor-co.description:
It is a code based on the concatenation of the 3-qubit repetition code in the Z- and X-Basis:
Explicit form of logical state: Bit flip errors are corrected by measuring -stabilizers: Phase flip errors are detected by measuring -stabilizers Properties: Complete code: arbitrary error correctable Degenerate code: several errors (e.g. and and ) have the same effect on logical states. Correction works if: correction attempt+ error=identity or a stabilizer

quantum-error-correction/kitaev's-toric-.title: Kitaev's toric code
quantum-error-correction/kitaev's-toric-.description:
Most commonly studied and experimentally pursued topological QEC code (experimental variant: „surface code“) square lattice with physical qubits located on the edges:
The vertices are a star operator and correspond to the action of the two qubits around them
All stabilizers mutually commute: , because plaquette and vertex operators share zero or two qubits (even number of anticommutes) They define the codespace: Here we consider lattice with periodic boundary conditions, i.e. embedded on the surface of a torus toric code The number of logical qubits can be determined by counting the number of physical qubits and independent constraints: plaquettes physical qubits (they re on the edges) plaquettes Z-stabilizers vertices X-stabilizers However, not all stabilizers are independent, the -th stabilizer is redundant: Only independent X,Z-stabilizersThis yields for The toric code can host 2 encoded logical qubits. This is a topological property, and independent of the lattice size or lattice structure (square lattice, hexagonal lattice, etc.)Logical operators correspond to non.contractable string operators winding around the hole and the handle of the torus:

All string operators commute with all stabilizers: and touch an even number of vertices, the first half and last half of the vertex is combined to one full vertex in the torus and touch an even number of plaquettes and of the same encoded qubit anticommute as required: They share exactly one single physical qubit and thus the number of anticommutes is uneven Logical operators of different needed qubits commute as required: thus Note that logical operators don‘t have unique qubit support (which means that they do not reach any arbitrary qubit normally) but can be deformed by multiplication with stabilizer operators which act trivially on logical states:
The deformed operators have the same action on logical states: Commutation and anticommutation relations are preserved under such continuous deformations:
Finally, one can write the logical basis states explicitly in the Z-Basis:Intuitively the following happens: We maximize the deformations of the strings, we can change the order of the terms because the logical operators commute with the stabilizers. The string could be deformed again generally. But in this case the state is the eigenstate for the projector of the -basis for all qubits, so we get an eigenvalue +1 for those projectors, so only the projectors remain. Remember that the last stabilizer is redundant and doesn‘t change the subspace of the projectors, meaning that the eigenvalues of the stabilizers already have been considered. Example L=2:
Errors on physical qubit show up as stabilizer „excitations“ (i.e. -1 eigenvalue measurements) of adjacent plaquette and vertex operators: Idea: Syndrome information is used to make best possible guess about the homological class of the set of errors which have occurred on the system Errors are created randomly and can diffuse We want to detect the errors quickly and reliably, and keep them localized and remove them


The error correction succeeds iff the loop (Correction attempt + Error chain ) is a contractable loop. Note, that the error chain is unknown. This is equivalent to a concatenation of stabilizer operators which don‘t change the codespace per definition. A non contractable loop leads to a logical operation equivalent to a logical error. Independently distributed, stochastic bit and phase flip errors on physical qubits occurring with probability can be corrected as long as . Decoding (i.e. determining a correction attempt given an error syndrome) an be done e.g. using the minimum-weight matching (MWPM) algorithm: find correction chain with overall shortest length

Planar surface codes are the physical implementation for the toric code.

headers.heading: Number of encoded logical qubits and logical operators

quantum-error-correction/quantum-error-c.title: Quantum Error Correction
quantum-error-correction/quantum-error-c.description:
The error rates of Quantum computation applications for guaranteed quantum advantage in the fault taulerant regime needed are . This is why Quantum Error Correction is very important in the Route to large-scale fault tolerant quantum computing. The coupling to the environment causes decoherence, for example magnetic field fluctuations. Dephasing can happen in a mixed state in an open system simulated by pure coherent superposition states, which leads to the loss of phase information. Other than that X-errors, Y-errors and Z-errors could happen as well as leakage and qubit loss.In classical error correction redundancies are introduced, for example n-bit repetition code, with majority vote as correction strategy. The repetition code fails if more than half of the bits suffer errors (bit flips).
Redundancy can not work in the quantum case due to the No-Cloning Theorem. Also we can't directly measure quantum states to find out about the errors that occurred. This leads to a collapse of the wave function., information about and lost (). even worse for entangled states by measuring one of the qubits only (). Measuring a single qubit collapses the state!Errors in quantum information are intrinsically continuous (rather than discrete): Example: Undesired perturbation Hamiltonian The effective error model we use in the following are stochastic, independently distributed (uncorrelated) X,Y,Z errors with probability .
By constructing logical qubits a quantum repetition code can be constructed such as the 3-qubit code. The code can detect errors and correct errors.Stabilizer states are a set of commuting observables which allow to describe a large class of multi-qubit states including all QEC codes considered here. Example: Bell states are stabilizer states, e.g.: Stabilizers and is a unique 2-qubit state for which All stabilizers commute and span a dimensional Abelian group. The Stabilizer state is uniquely fixed to by imposing for . The stabilizers span the n-dimensional subspace which is called the codespace. Also logical operators and can be defined which fulfill the following: Logical operators need to commute with the stabilizers, , and mutually anticommute, . Essentially one counts the number of anticommutes and if its even, hen it commutes otherwise it anticommutes. A distance- QEC code can correct errors. A distance- QEC code can detect errors. There exist weight- errors that directly induce an (undetectable) logical error
Generally QEC doesn‘t account for every single qubit error which is bound by the Quantum Hamming Bound
These codes can concatenated, the advantage is that the failure probability of logical qubits gets exponentially suppressed as the system size increases. Assuming the gate error probability is the failure probability for the 'th layer is . One example of such concatenation of the 3-qubit code is the 9-qubit Shor code. Other than that larger codes have a higher success probability. For an n-code with distance which is the minimal weight the error probability scales with for small . The Quantum Threshold Theorem assumes that every component can fail and guarantees an error probability where arbitrary quantum computations can be performed efficiently. In practice the error threshold are very demanding ().Idea: topology = robust global features which are invariant under local changes or perturbations assumption: noise and errors act locally Store quantum information spread out globally to protect it against noise The error thresholds are about and fault tolerant QC might be possible in practice! To what topological QEC codes are can be seen in .
Examples are the Kitaev‘s toric code and the Surface Code.

quantum-error-correction/quantum-hamming.title: Quantum Hamming Bound
quantum-error-correction/quantum-hamming.description:
How large must a Hilbert space be, so that one can accommodate a QEC code that fulfills the following conditions?
n qubits, encoded qubits, error correction works for up to errors.
Reasoning: For errors, there are possible locations, 3 types of errors (), thus a total number of possible errors The code space is -dimensional and each error is required to map the codespace to an -dim. Orthogonal subspace. All these subspace need to fit in the -dim. Hilbert space:
For 1 logical qubit (), 1 arbitrary correctable error (), this particularizes to: qubits needed for smallest complete code, with stabilizers and logical operators ( are cyclic permuations)

quantum-error-correction/quantum-thresho.title: Quantum Threshold Theorem
quantum-error-correction/quantum-thresho.description: There exists a physical error probability below which arbitrary and a bunch of ancilla qubits quantum computations can be performed efficiently.

quantum-error-correction/surface-code.ht.title: Surface Code
quantum-error-correction/surface-code.ht.description:
Planar (2D) lattice structures are suitable for practical realizations of topological QER codes. Planar surface code hosting one logical qubit: No periodic boundary conditions!
Logical () operators need to start over opposite smooth (rough) boundaries of the lattice respectively. Thus these are non-contractible strings starting and ending at boundaries (topological property) They fulfill the anticommutation relation and commute with all stabilizers. 4-qubit plaquette and vector stabilizers in the bulk Reduced 3-qubit -type and -type stabilizers at the smooth and rough boundaries Minimal surface codes of distance (one arbitrary error correctable):

quantum-mechanics/bloch-sphere.html.title: Bloch sphere
quantum-mechanics/bloch-sphere.html.description:
The Bloch sphere is a three dimensional representation of a two-level quantum mechanical system. The Hilbert Space is two dimensional and the representation is a sphere. Each point of outside and inside the sphere represents a valid state. The Sphere has a radius of 1.
For qubits the North Pole of the sphere is the state, the South Pole the state. Those are the eigenstates of the Z Gate. On the positive end of the x-axis the state is the - state, on the negative end the - state. Those are the eigenstates of the X Gate. For the y-axis those are - state, on the negative end the - state. Those are the eigenstates of the Y Gate. States on the surface of the Bloch sphere are Pure states. States inside the Bloch sphere are Mixed States. The state in the origin of the Bloch sphere is a Maximally mixed state. A pure state in the Bloch sphere can be represented as follows:
Rotations on the Bloch sphere are realized by the Rotation Gates, which can transform any pure state into another states on the Bloch sphere. An arbitrary rotation can be described as with .

quantum-mechanics/no-cloning-theorem.htm.description:
There exists no physical procedure to copy any arbitrary quantum state Proof:
Imagine that such an operation exists, which performs the following map:Consider two input states and : Take the inner product: which is only true, if and are either equal or orthogonal We can't copy states and that are not orthogonal.

quantum-mechanics/observations-on-preper.title: Observations on Preperations
quantum-mechanics/observations-on-preper.description:
The joint probability is the conditional times the marginal probability. The marginal probability of preparation equals the operator trace norm, while the conditional observation probability is obtained using deterministic state with trace-normalized operator. A preperation device is deterministic (probabilistic) with outcome(s), iff its marginal probability = . Normalization of a preparation by post-selection reverses the information flow to / from the lab. This makes the probabilistic device deterministic by changing the outcome to the device label. This means that we wait until the prepared state that is wanted gets triggered. To obtain the deterministic preperation one needs to trace-normalize . This describes the conditional probabilities of any later observation .By discarding outcomes we automatically discard the device , eliminating any functional dependence of on this future choice
It is also possible to coarse-grain over all outcomes to create a deterministic preparation device. Here two outcomes is reduced to one outcome. Discarding preparation outcomes effectively defines a new deterministic preperation device. The effective deterministic preperation describes the probabilities generated by any choice of later observation
Preparation probabilities of the reining pure preparations (eigenvalues of operator )
The number of refining preparations that contribute with (rank of operator ) The subspace spanned by these orthogonal eigenvectors (support space of operator ) Every preperation (operator) has a canonical coarse-graining simulation (diagonal form with subnormalized eigenvectors). Here we use orthogonal covectors ().
Thus we can see that the open-system quantum rules are the coarse-graining of closed-system rules (for preperations) can be simulated through coarse-graining with It can also be simulated through coarse-graining with Every preparation (operator) has a canonical simulation as a mixture which is the diagonal form with normalized eigenvectors.For the eigenvectors are and . Their observations are just because they are per definition orthonormal thus perfectly distinguishable.

quantum-mechanics/quantum-entanglement.h.title: Quantum Entanglement
quantum-mechanics/quantum-entanglement.h.description: If Product States are non-separable they are entangled. They can be semi entangled and fully entangled. All pure states that cannot be written as product states are entangled.Bell states are examples of entangled statesBell states are the simplest maximally entangled states. They form the Bell basis which is a four dimensional Hilbert Space for two qubits:

quantum-mechanics/rules-of-quantum-theor.title: Rules of Quantum Theory
quantum-mechanics/rules-of-quantum-theor.description:
In quantum theory switching between systems is always possible.through purifying and coarse graining respectively.Open quantum systems are obtained from closed quantum systems by discarding information.An Operational Circuit is directed from right to left and contain no loops. It is drawn as equations are written. It represents the joint probability of outcomes of an experiment as function of the events. All events jointly combine the probability of one possible set of outcomes (zyx) of the experiment. Orthogonal (co)vectors are denoted by the symbol .Rounded boxes Events Single wires Quantum Systems Double Wires Classical information about outcomes in the lab frameBoxes in time (in series) are connected by single wires (same lab frame) and boxes in space (in parallel) are not connected by single wires (different lab frames)A complete process involving the composition of quantum events that produce outcomes across multiple spatially separated laboratories, where each lab is accessible to agents who can communicate and condition or control their future choice of quantum operations or measurement devices based on prior information. Devices (or events they produce) are distinguished by their number of input and output quantum systems
An event is a specific outcome resulting from one use of a device (like a measurement or operation), chosen among several possible alternatives, and fully described in terms of what happened in the lab during that operation. Preparations are also called states collected into ensembles, are also called Effects collected into positive-operator-valued-measures, POVMs)
Quantum Theory is operationally defined by assigning mathematical objects to the systems Operational Quantity by a set rules () together with a rule to compute probabilities in the lab frame directly from these objects . There are three probabilistic concepts important for these rules (not specific to quantum theory): Probabilistic Deterministic: Number of outcomes (outgoing ) Conditioning outcome Conditioned choice: Outcomes Incomes (outgoing ) Non-pure Mixed: Probabilistic simulation with/out conditioning? These concepts are all effected by coarse graining. The devices are distinguished by the number of possible set of events (outcomes) that they produce in the lab. A deterministic device only produces one event (thus is omitted) while a probabilistic device have at least two possible events (thus is needed to specify). The deterministic device is not providing new information to the system. Those devices are indicated by a hat (e.g. )
Coarse Graining (denoted by the „garbage bin“ at the end of the double arrow) over all possible events of a probabilistic device produces (or simulates) a deterministic device. The coarse grained device generates the probabilities of the probabilistic device summed over the discarded outcomes. Discarding a system means discarding all outcomes of any observation test performed on it
Agents in the lab frame can choose which devices to use in a circuit during a experiment. Once a possible outcome has been chosen and run it collapses into that path. Conditioned choices are noted by an up arrow and a conditioning bar for probabilistic devices. For deterministic devices the conditioning bar is not necessary and only the device label is noted.
Outcomes produced probabilistically can be used to condition other devices, this is a simulation of a new device which jointly produces all the outcomes.
A pure event is an elementary event which has no underlying non-trivial probabilistic explanation. A pure event can not be simulated non-trivially. The purity of devices is the only operational assumption distinguishing the closed and open system quantum rules. Thus for pure events we use the notation for closed systems in the open system picture to indicate that. All pure events are Rank 1 projectors ( or Number of non-zero eigenvalues=1). Operators can only describe pure transformations! E.g. for preparation (This is similar for transformations and observations):
Example: can not be written as a probabilistic composition other than itself () and has a rank of 1 and is thus pure but can be written as a probabilistic composition of other preparations () and is thus non-pure. The rank is also 2.Devices that are mixed are always also non-pure, but not all non-pure events are mixed (except for preperations)! A mixed device can be simulated by coarse graining of device choices conditioned on a random variable. Thus the event is not mixed if the probabilities adding up are greater than one (). Example: is a mixed preperation. And as shown before on-pure. is not mixed because 1+1=2. This is also non-pure because the rank is 2. Thus this observation is neither pure nor mixed.
Note: To check operators against other operators (e.g. ) you check the eigenvalues against each other(e.g. ). There is no deterministic observation in the closed system.
Pretty good constructions reversing the causal order (, ) are indicated by overbar . The probabilities for the pretty good experiments are the same as for the original experiment. Mind that the order of devices don‘t change and use that the Trace is cyclic and the rules for complex conjugate in the braket formalism. In the open system the probabilities and in the closed system the amplitudes stay the same for . Open systems: With assumed invertible Closed systems: With assumed invertible
Perfectly distingushable preparations and observations are the only ones equal to their adjoint pretty good construction. So preparations and observations seem only the same if one assumes perfect distinguishability

index.html.description: Welcome to my Quantum Information notes from the Quantum Information lecture from RWTH in SS 25. Currently the notes contain Block 1+3 by Professor Müller and part of Block 2 of Wegwejis, lecture notes as well as exercises. To get started use search tree on the left. For questions and comments don't hesitate to write me an email.Author: Majeed Tanveer Email: majeed.tanveer@rwth-aachen.de

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.
